QuestionJSON.Question:
This question should be customized to appeal to Hispanic-Latinx high school students. If you would like to contribute content, please contact lt@atcsed.org

Lightning is very proud to be selected as their school representative for a new social media website for student leaders in high schools worldwide. The student leaders will discuss issues affecting teens worldwide.

Lightning comes across a post by Amani - also a new representative - from a school in the Middle East discussing surgical masks and hajibs. In response, Lightning sends a thumbs-up emoji 👍 with no further comment to show their approval.

Amani replies with the comment "Why are you so rude?" followed by three different sad face emojis.

Which of the following best explains why Amani did not view Lightning's comment as encouraging?
QuestionJSON.Answer1: In some portions of the Middle East, the thumbs-up gesture is considered an offensive insult.    However, in most other countries, it is a sign of approval.  The website was developed by a US company and did not consider this international issue.
QuestionJSON.Answer2: All Americans - especially teenagers - are rude
QuestionJSON.Answer3: Amani had planned to send three smiling face emojis but clicked on three different sad face emojis instead.
QuestionJSON.Answer4: In the Middle East, a frowning face emoji really means that one is happy.   However, in most other countries, it is a sign of sadness.
QuestionJSON.Explanation: There are many differences in how emoji use internationally and even within the same country. When developing a software product, one cannot assume that the colors, gestures, emojis, etc have the same meaning as they do in the U.S. When communicating internationally, be careful in use of emojis and consider using language that is difficult to misinterpret.
